ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I don't feel like I learned anything. Maybe patience because the class always felt so long.
How to write a long research paper; how to analyze and discuss longer readings

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This was my least favorite history seminar I've taken at Yale, and maybe even my least favorite class. There was no context or background information given for any of the readings, so we'd be reading about something really niche and specific with no background information. During the seminar Prof. Antonov often went on random tangents and recommended extra reading that had little to do with the material. We got no grades or feedback throughout the course because I guess the only graded assignment is the final paper, which is 18-20 pages. There's no actual assignment for the final paper, just that it has to be 18-20 pages, so I didn't know if I was supposed to be making an argument or compiling literature or what. I did almost all of the reading but don't feel like I learned anything, and I dreaded going to class each week.

Strengths: good course material, time range is not long enough so you can follow along
weaknesses: could use more of a textbook style reading just to give an overview for students that are not totally up to date on the basics
The frequency with which we met was a weakness, but the teacher was a strenghht

Strengths: Interesting material and readings;  organized assignments
Weaknesses: Discussions are unstructured and frequently people talk over one another; little feedback is given on assignments over the course of the term, making it difficult to assess how you are doing
Extremely well thought out readings and syllabus

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I wouldn't recommend this class to anyone, even if you're very interested in the topic. It was incredibly boring, I didn't get any feedback, and I don't feel like I've learned anything despite having done all the readings. The topic for each week was confusing. The final paper didn't come with any instructions. I have no idea how I'm going to do in the class, having received no feedback on anything. Prof. Antonov is slow to respond to emails, misses appointments, and is generally difficult to access outside of class.
I would recommend this class to a student that is really interested in Imperial and Soviet Russian history with a foundation of knowledge that is looking to garner more expertise.
Yes, Prof. Antonov is one of the best history professor I have had and the class covers a crucial period in Russian history from a variety of perspectives otherwise overlooked by academia.

Maybe. It's interesting material, and if you know how to approach the research assignment, it should not require a super heavy workload. That said, I felt that the discussions were too unstructured and too little feedback was given over the course of the term. This made it difficult for me to gauge my progress and hurt my satisfaction with the course.
